awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Surface Information for Quantitative Modeling of the Subsurface
awd_abstract_narration:
Surface connections, such as those among channels in river networks, are important for understanding the development and evolution of landscapes, such as densely populated coastal river deltas. Connections in the subsurface are critical in understanding groundwater flow and solute transport. Preferential flowpaths, in fact, can quickly deliver contaminants to water supply wells, a particularly important problem in densely populated coastal areas. Establishing a quantitative link between surface and subsurface patterns will greatly advance our capability to predict the movement of contaminants in groundwater, thus improving access to clean water and limiting pollution and health risks. We propose to investigate quantitatively how the dynamics of surface networks create subsurface networks, and thus determine how surface information can be used to predict properties of the subsurface. This will enable us to better predict sustainability and manage water resources in densely populated deltas such as the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta, where high concentrations of arsenic are widespread in the groundwater of the upper delta, and salinity problems are pervasive in the lower delta. The models and data analysis tools developed as part of this project will be released as open source and we will collaborate with Bangladeshi institutions to disseminate our findings. 
Our driving hypothesis is that the 3D subsurface structure can be predicted by combining information on (i) the modern surface network snapshot, (ii) the surface network kinematics (i.e., its temporal evolution), and (iii) accommodation and net sedimentation. We further hypothesize that (iv) the nature of the surface-to-subsurface translation exerts a major influence on structural connectivity and solute transport through the resulting aquifer system. Our goal is to develop new methods to translate surface channel networks to obtain quantitative models of subsurface architecture and flow and transport processes. We will perform this analysis with a combination of experimental, numerical modeling, and observational approaches and we will verify our findings by collecting lithologic and geochemical data in the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta. Our findings will provide critical information about the predictability of subsurface structure given the surface channel network and its kinematics, and will allow quantification of the factors influencing this predictability. The proposed work will also further the development of quantitative metrics of connectivity of surface networks and subsurface 3D structures and flowpaths, and improve our ability to model the subsurface structure of large deltaic systems where spatial heterogeneity and large spatial extent prevent full characterization via field observations. By extending this structural understanding to dynamic solute transport behavior, the proposed research will enhance the predictability of contaminant migration in highly heterogeneous systems.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The flow of groundwater is strongly influenced by spatial variation in the ability of subsurface materials to conduct flow (permeability). For the hundreds of millions of people living on deltas like the Ganges-Brahmaputra-Meghna Delta (GBMD) of Bangladesh, safe groundwater is a matter of life and death.

In sedimentary deposits like deltas, high permeability is generally associated with coarser sediment, often sands. Sand is in turn generally associated with former channels that have been buried by ongoing sedimentation. Hence, understanding groundwater flow in the subsurface requires understanding how channel networks on the surface create 3d sand deposits in the subsurface. The overall theme of this project is to address this by developing new methods for translating information on surface channel networks into better predictions of the distribution of groundwater-conducting sand deposits in the subsurface. Our work at UMN has focused on two related tasks, both based on experiments in which we collected data on both surface evolution of laboratory deltas and the deposits they created. The first was to develop methods for estimating how buried sand bodies are connected in space based on observations of the channels on the delta surface, specifically their geometry and migration. In field settings as well as most experiments, we have much more information available on the map-view distribution of channels than we do on their depth and detailed flow properties. We wanted to see how far we could get in reconstructing subsurface channel networks using just images of surface channels through time, together with overall sedimentation rate and rudimentary statistical information about channel depths. We found that, even though the reconstruction is imperfect, the method produces surprisingly good results when compared to the observed subsurface channel distribution. We believe this is the first-ever method for explicitly translating air photos and satellite images of channel networks into information about the flow pathways lying below the surface.

Our second research thread, carried out in parallel with Paola Passalacqua?s group at University of Texas, has been to develop a new method for quantifying channel evolution and change in active deltas. Channel migration strongly affects the shapes of flow-conducting sand bodies in the subsurface ? for instance, a channel that migrates laterally, or that widens over time, leaves behind a sand deposit that is wider than the channel itself, and hence more likely to intersect other sand deposits in the subsurface. With Prof. Passalacqua?s group, we adapted a well known method from fluid mechanics, called Particle-Image Velocimetry (PIV), to quantifying motion of channel banks. The new method produces vectors of local change from image sequences and is thus applicable to field as well as laboratory image data. Summarizing the vector results, we found that the two banks of braid channels migrate independently of, and away from, each other, leading to general widening of the channel. We also found that an individual channel lifespan is limited to the time needed for it to roughly triple its initial width. At the point, the channel bed has risen via deposition to the point where the flow finds a more advantageous path. This sets a useful cap on the maximum dimensions individual braid channels can reach and also bounds the shapes of subsurface conduits they can produce.

All in all, our work has given us new ways to look at an image of the channels on a delta, especially one like the GBMD that is predominantly braided, and have a well grounded method for estimating the geometry of the sand bodies they have left under the surface. This in turn helps us to better predict where water and contaminants will flow underground.
